I found that my Thunderbird profile folder is very large at 565GB, but my email occupies only 40GB on the server. I checked the contents of my configuration folder and found many files named nstmp-1 nstmp-2 etc, dozens of them, which are taking up a lot of my hard disk space. I want to know what these nstmp files are for, can I delete them, and what impact will deleting them have on my emails? Thank you all.

content: Dat is binnen Thunderbird in principe niet mogelijk tenzij de computer continue ingeschakeld blijft. Vaak is het wel mogelijk om bij de provider e-mailregels in te stellen voor het verwerken van e-mailberichten. Kijk daarvoor in de webmailversie van de account.

content:
re:"A newer version of Thunderbird may have made changes to your profile which are no longer compatible with this older version.

That means you were previously using a newer version than the one you have currently got installed.

Try this:

I'm assuming you are using a Windows OS and have used a Thunderbird installation from this link so profile is in the default location. https://www.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/all/

  1. Exit Thunderbird
  2. In windows search bottom left of screen type: %Appdata% - see image as guide
  3. Select the %Appdata% file folder option
  4. Select 'Roaming'
  5. Select 'Thunderbird'
  6. Select the original profile name
  7. Look for this file and delete it : 'compatibility.ini'
  8. Start Thunderbird.
creator: Toad-Hall

content: click view>folders and tick 'folder pane headers' if menu bar is not visible, press alt key first
